comments.commentBody: I'm convinced that Will and/or Mr. Polin sued the Mo/42 clue just to bamboozle Yankee fans.
J, don't  you mean Dodger fans?

.
We Yankee fans are easily bamboozled. It's terrifying actually, to consider the mass hysteria that once had thousands of people believing the future of the franchise would be built around Phil Hughes.

But I don't reckon Mr. Polin uses his considerable creativity to shoot fish in that barrel. My guess is the 42 clue was perpetrated at Puzzle Central.

Once the rebus was found, the theme was easy. (I was one of those kids who memorized the song.) However I was not impressed with the rest of the puzzle.  I'm not familiar with ULTRA as a noun; GO UP does not mean burst into flames..it's part of the phrase "Go up in flames";  I still don't get  ATNO at all and am pretty sure that ATIP is not used in that sense.  I worked this one with a friend and we both vote "Nope."

For every post which claims “She should have complied- this would have never happened,” put the shoe on the other foot and think may be a decent police officer should have taken Officer Encinia aside and said, “Not for nothing but you need to tone it down a little out there..” If some officer had the courage to do that- may be, “this would have never happened.”

Landlords can make a lot of money AND still retain relationships with the tenants whose community appeal are significantly responsible for the high rates they are able to command.  A smart landlord looks to maximize profits for the long run and not just bilk the moment to make a quicker buck that can backfire when the economic engine of the tenants are forced to relocate.

And what about that assessment wasn't true? Another landlord who pushed out an iconic and beloved restaurant from its home, rather than negotiate with the current tenant out of good will and respect? Instead to replace it with a restaurant chain having no relationship to the neighborhood for probably 15 times the rent?
It's interesting how cavalier people can be about a landlord or developer amassing inconceivable profits for himself on the backs of people who actually create something for the city and its patrons.
The reason the landlord was able to "maximize his investment property" was because visionary creators like Danny Meyer and the staff at USC turned around an entire neighborhood!

And after all that sturm und angst among Times commenters about how another universally beloved ancient institution that represented the city in more equal days was being forced to end its relationship with an increasingly soulless city because another greedy landlord actually believed he had a right to maximize his investment property.

.
If you think it was fun to have your rebii not fit (I know, no one thinks it's fun), wait'll you try downloading the solutions to either or both July 19 "Variety Puzzles".

Not helter-skelter at all. And remember, we pay extra for this service (and no one will disclose how many solvers are enduring these snafus, or how much $$ is being collected monthly for Crossword Subscriptions).

I can find out the cost of a full-page ad.

I can find out how much revenue NYT gets from print ads.

I can find out how much revenue NYT gets from selling print papers.

But we're paying for the software to sometimes act as if QC is a dirty word (like Santa's laugh). And I have yet to hear a single person say they know how much we are cumulatively paying.

Oh, and when the Crossword doesn't work in a certain platform, or there's a typo, or whatever, WE are the ones who tell the payee that there's an issue. Just hours ago, Elke/Robert reported what time the puzzle was available online in their distant nation filled with loonies. No one paid them for that QC report. Why do we do that, all of us? My best guess is that for obvious reasons we feel neighborly toward Deb. And I hope she earns a bonus based on community-building (or herding cats, take your pick).

But we're still paying above regular subscription price for a product that errs almost as often as David Brooks does.

I finished the puzzle with Anadem and had to google it, but when I thouoght of diadem from an old church siong, I like it. I thought Jails-cans was cool, and havintg escaped a house fire wearing only a pair of drawer, I had a real understanding of seeing all I owned GO UP. Agree with you on ATIP. A better clue for that is "the race is fixed," e.g.

.
Amy (who is a non-Deb blogger) pointed up another issue with GO UP.

Seems that 2 clues have "go" in them. I think both Down clues; not too far from each other. One is for SATINE. I'm not bothered in the least by all the "go" appearances. I mostly dislike GOUP because it reminds me of Gwyneth Paltrow.

Ted, I'm disappointed your grid didn't have SUFFE as mine did. I would have liked collaborating on a coinage. But if the word appears only in my grid, it's just an assemblage of letters.

Anyway, my idea would have been pronunciation soof; derivation, strange variant of SUFFRAGE. Definition could have been a collective noun for people who have declared candidacy (esp. for a Presidential nomination) but have not yet been part of a debate, primary, caucus, or other formal step in the process. "The Democratic field has more Northeasterners than any SUFFE in recent memory."

Before I critique, I want to point out that my computer gives an incorrect solution. It insists on SATINES instead of SALTINES, which leaves an L short in the rebus. Not sure why this happened, but it didn't make my solving experience any nicer.

I think Deb was far too kind here. I hate rebuses, but that wasn't the real problem in this puzzle. When I was all done, there were a bunch of clues and answers where I would just look and say- really?

This puzzle fit like a right glove on a left hand. Let's start by saying that no puzzle should being with the answer ASTA. Really, this is super crosswordese any way you dress it up. There were a bunch of answers that I am sure would pass the Martin test (if you can find a definition that fits, it is okay), but don't make anyone smile.

cans- jails ugh.
zealot-ultra feh.
burst into flames- go up? partial nonsense
tosspot- dipso???
on tenterhooks- atip???

This was just for starters. Then there was "SERIES E" crossing ANADEM. That's Saturday hard.

Anyway, I hated it. Nothing else to say.

You really think this is equivalent to isis? No wonder we have such poor race relations in this country. I am a white male and have never spoken to a police officer the way she did. These types if situations will end when people like her realize that all races have to avoid sticking their thumb in the eye of a police officer.
How do you know that? Where have you seen that reported?

If bail isn't posted then Ms. Blands would not have been released until after arraignment but my guess, based solely on her conduct, is that she had a bench warrant out of another jurisdiction.

It frightens me that many of the commentators here know little about the duties of law enforcement or the criminal justice system. Due to this ignorance the system is in jeopardy.

" If either one of them was willing to display a little less ego and a little more humility"

You depict the situation as if they were peers. Aren't you forgetting something? The power imbalance is enormous. The cop holds all the power, indeed, lethal force, for that reason he is *theoretically* highly trained (!) because he has an enormous responsibility to retain his composure in the face of no matter what verbal displays of ego or lack of humility.
She didn't back talk him.  She obeyed him and answered his questions.  She was irritated, clearly, but she wasn't acting like an immature jerk,

I think you have it all wrong. She was not arrested for failure to signal. She was arrested for not cooperating and following the commands of a police officer, and for clearly resisting arrest. A little fine-tuned thinking goes a long way.

So... no matter what command an officer issues, obey or you may be tasered/choked/shot. If the command from an ill-trained officer is blatantly harassing or downright illegal? Doesn't matter, shut up and obey or you may end up dead.

Where does the power of the police end, then?
It seems clear that the cop wasn't  the only one looking for a fight.
42 is the atomic number of molybdenum.  It's the same "no" for number that got people last Sunday.
Even if true, what relevance does all that have to the police officer's behaviour  in this specific situation?
So in other words they are not very smart bullies who think they are above the law.

Gustav, you old rascal!
I want to see the video of minutes before the assault on Ms. Bland. Do you have the link that shows the police officer, Encinia, chasing down a car....where can I get a look at that video? Do you have the link?
It happens every day.

It is not justifiable in any way, yet it is the lay of the land. If you are not polite in an encounter with the police; if you do not comply with their direct orders; if you act at all uppity--especially while black--you may be arrested and/or beaten and/or killed.

Yes, they may badger you; confuse you; intimidate you; provoke you, ask you absurd questions; give you orders that seem arbitrary and irrational. That is the culture of policing in the United States. They do it because they can. Because they believe they require intimidation and establishing domination in order to do their job. And often because it helps them obtain evidence to make an arrest. As awful as this is to contemplate, almost all of it is legal.

We must understand these dynamics. We must understand that in so many encounters with the police, our purported rights are a cruel joke.

Yes, we must be extra nice to Officer (Un)Friendly. We must get clarification about the distinction between their requests and their direct orders. If it is an order, we must comply in order to protect ourselves, no matter how scared or angry or incredulous we are at their treatment of us.

Be safe. Avoid contact with the police. If you are stopped, have a plan to conduct yourself in a way that will keep you out of jail, in one piece, and alive.

https://www.aclu.org/files/kyr/kyr_english.pdf

From the comments of many, apparently her biggest error was not unfailingly polite. This "error" on her part makes it all her fault in the eyes of some. Yet it is interesting that this carries another implied part. Be rude and the police are given free rein to set you straight. In short, be nice or something bad is gonna happen to you. Why is this considered justified by people? Police are NOT drafted, the volunteer. They know the risks and the pay rate. Is the only response they have when someone is being rude is to threaten to "light them up"? What should have been a simple warning or a traffic summons was escalated by the officer. Needless and pointless orders, an ever changing charge for a bogus arrest and then the rather odd death in custody.

Bottom line, better be extra nice to Officer Friendly or he might just decide to give you a bit of a tune up and stick you in jail because you were not polite.
Boy, did you hit the nail on the head!

Those blame-the-victim/should have just obeyed apologists; let us change the scenario a bit. A big Black male police officer about 260 lbs, pulls over a petite white female, smoking a cigarette and none to happy about it; a change lane violation of all things. She vents her displeasure and blows smoke in his face. Big Black Police Officer demands she get out of the car; she refuses; he yanks her out and slams her head onto the pavement- all the while the dash cam and audio are recording: Should I continue or will you fill in the blanks of what happens next.

I am horrified at some of the comments that blame the victim. Every day when I drive to work, I see people turning who don't use their turn signals. They do not get pulled over, threatened, and put in jail.

Some commenters are saying (as in earlier incidents), that the victim should have obeyed the officer and the implication is that being in jail for days, and ultimately dying, were somehow deserved.

How many right wing people claim they don't have to obey the law if Obama had something to do with it? How many people get involved with paranoid situations like Jade Helm or Cliven Bundy and are willing to threaten law enforcement? Not one person waving their guns at officers and shouting at them (and refusing to obey them) ended up in jail and dead.

Why is it even a lawful command for a police officer to order someone to put out their cigarette? What does that have to do with law enforcement? The smoking police? This was an unarmed woman who didn't signal.

It is sheer racism frankly to have such double standards in these situations. We do not yet know what happened here, but the rush to blame the victim on the part of some people reflects the worse of the current right wing's prejudices.

He begins to push it when he says: You seem very irritated. Then when he continues: Put out your cigarette. And so on.

Why didn't he jsut give her a ticket (or a warning) and leave?Professionally, that would have concluded the incident.
A very good question. I wish someone would answer it. I wish some journalist would explain it.
Thank you. Nice to have a fresh view on this outrage.

On the audio she tells the cop that she's epileptic. Is it possible she had a fatal seizure and the supposed suicide was either staged or simply reported?   Are there photos of her body while hanging?
She filled a form and stated that she tried to commit suicide by pills and losing her baby. Reported Dallas TV/paper today.
Your're not alone, bud. We're all suspicious.

Another question to add to Charles' excellent list: I've uploaded a number of videos to youtube as a web series creator and producer, and I've never heard of an upload where the audio came through completely intact but the video 'looped.' If there's a glitch, BOTH glitch or stall, and youtube usually tells you with 'failed to upload.' How many instances of this 'uploading glitch' have ever happened to youtubers?

Yet another one: Has anyone outside of the police independently verified Ms. Bland's previous 'suicide attempt'? Awfully, awfully convenient for that to come out now.

I don't necessarily think Sandra Bland was deliberately murdered; maybe she was tasered too hard, maybe her head was slammed against the wall and she died as a result. I just don't believe suicide by garbage bag.
Agreed.  And was the other driver that the officer pulled over black?  Or a woman?  I wonder about the possibility of profiling here.

AACNY, let's distinguish between the abuse Presidents Obama and Bush faced.  I cannot deny that Bush face lots of abuse from part of the public, provoked largely by his own actions and unprompted by an organized media attack.  By contrast, he did not have to face the organized double-barreled hostility that our current president has borne with dignity; he got it from powerful right-wing media and their devotees - OK, no surprise there - but also from a congressional opposition that determined on the very day of his inauguration that it would refuse to cooperate with any of his proposals, whether it agreed with them or not, simply because they were his proposals, period, full stop.  In the American system, the Congress is part of the government, but the Republican opposition refused to have any part of governing.

When the ancient Old Kingdom collapsed because the Nile ran dry for decades, Egyptians ate each other. Now the Nile is being diverted upstream of Egypt to irrigate farmland for food production for China.

Well overall this is not a major problem. All through history, when societies failed to measure and control their resources, inevitably scarcity would destroy those societies. The people of Rapanui (Easter Island) are a good example, they cut down all the trees and suddenly had no way to make boats. So if California keeps wasting water, for the rest of the country things like inexpensive almonds and grapes will vanish, and for California the population itself will have to move out. Can't live without water, and if we have to abandon an entire state due to being blind to onrushing doom, I guess people have to learn things the hard way.

At any rate, if y'all think this is bad, wait until you see the entire Mideast in a few decades. It is not going to be pretty, and things like cannibalism are likely outcomes.
